race.name: Southern Cross Gravel
race.tagline: Punchy Georgia mountain gravel with a winery finish and the best post-race party in the Southeast.

vitals.aid_stations: Miles 35, 70. Water, snacks, mechanical. Sparse—35+ miles between stations.

climate.description: Cold starts (35-45°F), warming to 55-70°F by midday. March brings 15-20% rain probability and mud risk.
challenges: Red clay becomes impassable 'peanut butter' when wet
Weather-dependent course difficulty—dry is fast, wet is survival

terrain.surface: 70% gravel/dirt forest roads, 20% paved connectors, 10% technical doubletrack/singletrack. Red Georgia clay—smooth when dry, slick when wet.
features: Woody Gap climb (1,200 ft at mile 25)

biased_opinion.summary: Southern Cross is what happens when you build a gravel race for climbers, descenders, and wine drinkers. This is NOT Kansas. It's the North Georgia Appalachians—steep, punchy, unrelenting. The Montaluce Winery start/finish is chef's kiss: you suffer for 5-7 hours on red clay climbs, then roll into a vineyard where volunteers hand you wine, BBQ, and a chair with a mountain view. It's the only gravel race where you might actually want to stay at the finish line longer than it took to ride the race. The course is honest suffering—no gimmicks, just real North Georgia topography. If you're a diesel engine who thrives on sustained power, this will hurt. If you're a punchy climber who can recover on descents, you'll love it.
strengths: Montaluce Winery finish—wine, BBQ, live bluegrass, sunset over the vineyard
Honest mountain gravel—rewards climbers and descenders, not diesel engines
Small-town Georgia hospitality—family-friendly, accessible race director
weaknesses: Mud lottery—if it rains the week before, course becomes significantly harder (18% DNF in 2023)
Limited aid stations—35+ miles between stations means self-sufficiency required
Lodging pressure—Dahlonega is tiny, hotels fill fast, likely driving from Gainesville
Cold March starts—35-40°F mornings, dress wrong and you're numb for an hour
Day-of packet pickup only—no race-eve pickup option
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want flat, fast, tactical pack racing, this isn't it. If you want punchy climbs, technical descents, and a winery finish that makes you forget your legs hurt—Southern Cross delivers. This is the Southeast's answer to mountain gravel: smaller field, bigger personality, and a post-race party that justifies the entry fee alone. You'll either love the relentless rollers or walk up Woody Gap. But you'll definitely drink good wine at the end.

black_pill.title: THE RED CLAY MUD LOTTERY
black_pill.reality: Southern Cross is two completely different races depending on whether it rained the week before. Dry conditions? Smooth, fast forest roads with grippy clay. Recent rain? Thick, slick, drivetrain-clogging peanut butter that turns steep climbs into hike-a-bike nightmares and descents into white-knuckle survival. There's no B-plan course. The 2023 edition saw 18% DNF due to mud and mechanicals. If you're flying in from out of state, you're gambling on Georgia weather a week before race day.
consequences: You'll spend $500-800 (flights, rental car, lodging, entry) for a race that's easy-to-hard based on weather
Mud conditions mean mechanical hell—clogged drivetrains, flats, brake rub
Limited aid (35+ miles between stations) means if you bonk, you're walking
Cold starts (35-40°F) in March catch riders underdressed—numb hands for the first hour
black_pill.expectation_reset: Come prepared for mountain gravel, not rolling roads. Bring low gearing (compact or 1x with 42t+ bailout), aggressive tires if rain is forecast, and layers for cold starts. Check the forecast religiously the week before. If it's been dry, you're in for a fast, fun day. If it's been wet, you're in for a survival slog. Either way, the wine at the finish helps.

logistics.lodging_note: Limited options in Dahlonega. Book 2-3 months ahead. Gainesville, GA (20 miles) has more hotels.
logistics.parking: Free at Montaluce Winery (start/finish). Arrive by 6:30 AM for good spot.
logistics.travel_summary: Atlanta airport accessible but 1.5-hour drive. Rental car mandatory. Lodging tight—book early or stay in Gainesville.
logistics.food_options: 2 on-course aid stations (miles 35, 70). Post-race: wine, BBQ, live music at Montaluce Winery.
logistics.camping: Limited on-site camping at private properties (sold separately)

course_description.character: Constant elevation change with no extended flats. Punchy, steep pitches (8-12% typical) spread throughout. This is NOT a power race—it's a climbing and bike-handling test. North Georgia Appalachian terrain: relentless rollers, technical descents, and forest road gravel.

suffering_zones.name: Woody Gap Climb
suffering_zones.description: The first major test: 1,200 ft over 5 miles (avg 5%, pitches to 12%). You're barely warmed up when it starts. Riders on road gearing walk here. Sets the tone for the day.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Comes early when legs are fresh but not warmed up. Sustained effort with punchy steep sections. No bailout—you're committed once you start climbing.

suffering_zones.name: Blood Mountain Descent
suffering_zones.description: Technical, loose, rocky descent. Rewards good descenders, punishes the timid. Line choice matters. Sharp rocks mean flat risk is high.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Technical skill test after a big climb. Loose gravel and rocks. Fast riders gap here; cautious riders lose time.

suffering_zones.name: Jacks Gap Climb
suffering_zones.description: 800 ft climb when legs are already cooked. 'Just keeps going' per riders. Mental grind as much as physical.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Comes at mile 55 when glycogen is depleted. No recovery before or after—you're in the pain cave.

suffering_zones.name: Bull Mountain Loop
suffering_zones.description: 15 miles of relentless rollers. No recovery, no flats. Constant up-down-up-down. Where the race breaks people mentally.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: No sustained climbs to settle into rhythm. Constant power surges. Mentally exhausting—feels like it will never end.

course_description.signature_challenge: The first major test: 1,200 ft over 5 miles (avg 5%, pitches to 12%). You're barely warmed up when it starts. Riders on road gearing walk here. Sets the tone for the day.

history.origin_story: Steady cult following. 250-300 riders annually. Regional Southeast field with repeat participants.
notable_moments: 2023: Wet week before race. Muddy course, 18% DNF due to conditions and mechanicals.
